H0.text: Oxygen must be combined with a halogen to give the halogen a positive oxidation number.

H1.text: Nitrogen must be combined with a halogen to give the halogen a positive oxidation number.

H2.text: Calcium must be combined with a halogen to give the halogen a positive oxidation number.

H3.text: Carbon must be combined with a halogen to give it a positive oxidation number.

A4.text: The oxidation state of oxygen is −2 in almost all known compounds of oxygen.

A5.text: In ionic compounds, the oxidation numbers are the same as the element's ionic charge.

A6.text: Group 1 and group 2 metals in compounds have OS = +1 and +2, respectively.

A7.text: Chlorine, oxidation number 0, forms chloride (Cl−; oxidation number −1) and chlorate(V) (ClO−3; oxidation number +5).

A8.text: Perchlorate contains chlorine in its highest oxidation number (+7).
